What are selective forces behind bee reaction to smoke & fire as an adaptation?
Question
  • Feb 2017
Reaction of honeybees to smoke/fire is well known: they get less aggressive, begin to gulp honey etc.; the tranquilizing effect of smoke is widely used by beekeepers around the world. However, is such reaction known also in wild, not domesticated bees, bees of different species? And, was an original function of this adaptation (as it is probably not the adaptation to human beekeepers), for example, an reaction to wildfires in nature, somewhere mentioned or recorded, please?

  • 3 Answers
Humans as true parasites?
Question
  • Jan 2013
Humans in certain cultures have adapted behaviors that could be defined as true parasitism. Some pastoralist tribes of Africa (Maasai, Samburu - are there any others cutlures in the world?) drain blood from the carotid artery of the cow, and collect it as a source of protein (mixing with milk, cooking etc...) The cattle is kept alive before, during, and after the process, meaning that the blood harvesting could be seen as a true parasitic behavior. Is somebody aware of other human true parasitic behavioural/cultural adaptations? Is it possible to consider keeping the animals for milk, eggs or other products as a true parasitism?
